column1: '''Hamfast Gamgee''', better known as '''the Gaffer''', was a [[Hobbits
column2: Hobbit]] of [[the Shire]], and the father of [[Samwise Gamgee]].

column1: Hamfast was born in 2926, the third son of [[Hobson
column2: Hobson Gamgee]], who was a roper by trade.<ref name="Gamgee">{{App

column1: He entered the service of his relative, [[Holman Greenhand]], and became a gardener. One of his first jobs was tending the garden of [[Bag End]]. On [[22 June]], {{TA
column2: 2942}}, he and Holman tried frantically to keep the garden in order during the auction of the presumed-dead [[Bilbo Baggins]]. It is likely that at this time he already lived at Number 3, [[Bagshot Row]].

column1: Hamfast became a gardener in his own right in about {{TA
column3: Guide}}, p. 187</ref>, and a local expert on [[potatoes]]. He married [[Bell Gamgee
column4: Bell Goodchild]], and they had six children: [[Hamson Gamgee
column9: Marigold]].<ref name="Gamgee"/> Sam became Hamfast's apprentice.

column1: Sam took over most of his father's work, who had become too old for the laborous work. He became known as the "Gaffer", a name Sam uses more often than "Hamfast".

column1: [[Wiktionary:gaffer|Gaffer]] is a colloquial word for "old man".
In the illustrated short story ''[[Mr. Bliss]]'', there is a resident in the village named Gaffer Gamgee who struggles to listen to the discussion between Mr Binks and Sergeant [[Boffin Family
column2: Boffin]] about whether Mr Bliss should be locked up for failure to pay for his car. Sergeant Boffin also has a son named [[Sam]].<ref>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], ''[[Mr. Bliss]]'' (2011 edition), p. 63</ref>

column1: In [[Letter 257]], [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] recounts a holiday to Lamorna Cave in the early 1930's. To amuse his sons, he named a local Gaffer Gamgee. This "curious local character" was "an old man who used to go about swapping gossip and weather-fashion and such like". The surname was chosen because it alliterated with Gaffer.
Tolkien had several encounters with actual Gamgees, however. [[wikipedia:Gamgee Tissue
column2: Gamgee Tissue]], a word young Ronald considered comical, was named after [[wikipedia:Sampson Gamgee
column3: J. Sampson Gamgee]] (1828-1886), a famous [[Birmingham]] surgeon,<ref>{{L
column4: 72}}</ref> whilst in the Black Country dialect cotton wool was referred to as "gamgee".<ref>{{webcite
column5: website=[http://sedgleymanor.com/ The Ancient Manor of Sedgley]
column8: accessed=9 September 2014}}</ref> The Gamgees were notorious surgeons - years later, Dr. Leonard Gamgee tended those war-wounded, including Lieutenant Tolkien.{{fact}}
